questions.text: Patient diagnosed with chronic suppurative otitis media has been planned for Tympanoplasty. All among the following are landmarks to identify the commonly injured nerve during this procedure except
questions.explanation:
MIDDLE EAR AND MASTOID:

1) Processus Cochleariformis (Option C)
  • tympanic segment of nerve starts at this level

2) Oval Window & Horizontal Canal (Option A)
  • runs superior to the oval window (stapes) and inferior to the horizontal canal

3) Short Process of Incus (Option D)
  • medial to the short process of incus at the aditus

4) Pyramid
  • passes behind the pyramid and posterior tympanic sulcus

5) Digastric ridge
  • nerve exits the mastoid at the anterior end of the digastric ridge.

PAROTID:

1) Cartilaginous Pointer
  • located 1 cm deep, slightly anterior and inferior to this triangular cartilage

2) Tympanomastoid Suture
  • lies 6-8 mm deep to the suture

3) Styloid Process
  • crosses lateral to the styloid process

4) Posterior Belly of Digastric (Option B)
  • between the styloid process and posterior belly of the digastric muscle

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the development of ear ossicles and inner ear is false?

options.label: A
options.text: Malleus and incus are developed from first pharyngeal arch

options.label: B
options.text: Stapes footplate is developed from otic capsule

options.label: D
options.text: A part of the stapes develops from the third pharyngeal arch

questions.correct_answer: D. A part of the stapes develops from the third pharyngeal arch
questions.explanation:
Ossicle

Embryonic Source

Malleus

Mesoderm of the first pharyngeal arch

Incus

Mesoderm of the first pharyngeal arch

Stapes
  • Footplate and annular ligament of stapes-Otic capsule
 
  • Rest-Second pharyngeal arch

questions.text: Match the layers of tympanic membrane to the germinal layer from which it developes. Layers of tympanum Germinal layer a.Epithelial layer 1.Ectoderm b.Fibrous layer 2.Endoderm c.Mucosal layer 3.Mesoderm
Which of the following structures pass through the internal auditory canal?

options.label: A
options.text: Facial nerve, cochlear nerve, and trigeminal nerve

options.label: B
options.text: Cochlear nerve, vestibular nerve, and facial nerve

options.label: C
options.text: Optic nerve, oculomotor nerve, and facial nerve

options.label: D
options.text: Glossopharyngeal nerve, vagus nerve, and accessory nerve

questions.correct_answer: B. Cochlear nerve, vestibular nerve, and facial nerve

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with progressive right-sided hearing loss, intermittent tinnitus, and a sensation of fullness. An audiogram shows significant sensorineural hearing loss. Which structure is most likely affected?
questions.explanation:
Inner hair cells

Outer hair cells

Total count and Rows

3500 and 1 row

12,000 and 3-4 rows

Shape

Flask shaped

Cylindrical shape

Nerve supply

Mainly afferent

Mainfly efferent

Function
  • Transmit auditory stimuli
  • More resistant
  • Modulate function of inner hair cells.
  • Easily damaged by ototoxic drugs and high-intensity noise

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly identifies the primary ionic components of endolymph and perilymph in the cochlea?

options.label: A
options.text: Endolymph is high in sodium (Na+), and perilymph is high in potassium (K+).

options.label: B
options.text: Endolymph is high in potassium (K+), and perilymph is high in sodium (Na+).

options.label: C
options.text: Both endolymph and perilymph are high in sodium (Na+).

options.label: D
options.text: Both endolymph and perilymph are high in potassium (K+).

questions.correct_answer: B. Endolymph is high in potassium (K+), and perilymph is high in sodium (Na+).
questions.explanation:
Sodium

Potassium

Endolymph

5

144

Perilymph

140

10

questions.text: In the cochlea, high-frequency sounds are primarily detected at which location along the basilar membrane?

Which of the following accurately describes the anatomy and function of the semicircular canals? The lateral, posterior, and superior canals are oriented perpendicular to each other. Each semicircular canal has an ampullated end that contains the crista ampullaris, which detects angular acceleration. The membranous ducts within the bony canals are filled with perilymph and surrounded by endolymph. The crus commune is formed by the non-ampullated ends of the posterior and superior canals and opens into the vestibule. The semicircular canals are located within the bony labyrinth in the frontal bone.
questions.explanation:
Semicircular canals

Location

Within the bony labyrinth in the temporal bone.(statement 5 ruled out )

Function

The semicircular canals aid in balance and spatial orientation.

Canals and Planes
  • 3 Canals: Lateral Canal; Posterior Canal; Superior Canal
  • Each canal is perpendicular to each other. (statement 1)
  • Three canals open into the vestibule through five openings.

 

Fluids

  • Membranous semicircular ducts are inside the bony semicircular canals
  • Membranous semicircular ducts are filled with endolymph and surrounded by perilymph (statement 3 ruled out )

Ampullae and Crus Commune
  • Each canal has an ampullated end, a wider portion containing a sensory structure called the crista ampullaris. (statement 2)
    • Detect angular acceleration (head rotation): Cristae ampullaris contain hair cells that sense endolymph movement and send balance signals to the brain.
  • The non-ampullated ends of the posterior and superior canals merge to form a common channel called the crus commune before entering the vestibule. (statement 4)

questions.text: Which structure in the vestibule of the inner ear contains the structure involved in detecting linear acceleration and deceleration.?
questions.explanation:
Parts of the Inner Ear

The inner ear, or labyrinth, is essential for hearing and balance and is located within the temporal bone. It consists of the bony labyrinth and the membranous labyrinth.

Bony Labyrinth

A rigid structure filled with perilymph (a sodium-rich fluid), it has three main parts:

  1. Vestibule: Central part connecting to the cochlea and semicircular canals.
    • Bony Recesses in the vestibule contains the utricle and saccule (part of the membranous labyrinth).
      • Spherical Recess: Contains the saccule, a membranous sac involved in detecting linear acceleration and deceleration.
      • Elliptical Recess: Contains the utricle, which works with the saccule to aid in balance and spatial orientation.
    • Oval Window: Located on the vestibule’s lateral wall, it connects to the middle ear.
    • Openings of the Semicircular Canals: The three semicircular canals (lateral, posterior, and superior) have five openings into the vestibule, enabling detection of head rotations.
    • Opening of the Vestibular Aqueduct: Positioned below the elliptical recess, it allows the passage of the endolymphatic duct, which carries endolymph within the membranous labyrinth.
  2. Semicircular Canals: Three canals (lateral, posterior, and superior) positioned at right angles to detect rotational head movement. Each has an ampulla containing the crista ampullaris for sensory function.
  3. Cochlea: A spiral structure essential for hearing, divided into three chambers (scala vestibuli, scala tympani, and scala media). The scala vestibuli and tympani contain perilymph and communicate via the helicotrema, while the scala media houses the organ of Corti, which converts sound vibrations into electrical signals.

Membranous Labyrinth

A delicate system within the bony labyrinth, filled with potassium-rich endolymph, it includes:

  1. Cochlear Duct (Scala Media): Inside the cochlea, it separates the scala vestibuli and scala tympani and contains the organ of Corti for hearing.
  2. Utricle and Saccule: Membranous sacs in the vestibule responsible for detecting linear acceleration and balance. They are connected via the utriculosaccular duct.
  3. Semicircular Ducts: Membranous ducts within the bony semicircular canals, contributing to balance.
  4. Endolymphatic Duct and Sac: Extending from the utricle and saccule, the duct ends in the endolymphatic sac, important in surgical treatments for conditions like Ménière's disease.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient is undergoing a mastoidectomy for chronic mastoiditis. During surgery, the surgeon encounters a structure that obstructs access to the deeper petrosal air cells. What is the most likely anatomical structure causing this surgical challenge?
questions.explanation:
Korner's septum
  • Korner's septum is a bony plate in the mastoid, separating the superficial squamosal air cells from the deeper petrosal air cells.
  • It is a remnant of the developmental petrosquamous suture.

Surgical Importance
  • During Mastoidectomy: Korner's septum is important when removing infected mastoid air cells.
  • Challenges in Locating the Antrum: A prominent Korner's septum can block access to the mastoid antrum, complicating surgery.
  • Incomplete Disease Removal: If Korner's septum is not fully removed, deeper infected air cells may be missed, leading to persistent or recurrent infection.

questions.text: Which of the following describes the posterior boundary of MacEwen's triangle?

options.label: B
options.text: Posterosuperior part of the bony external auditory canal

options.label: C
options.text: A tangent line drawn from the external auditory canal

questions.correct_answer: C. A tangent line drawn from the external auditory canal
questions.explanation:
MacEwen's Triangle (Suprameatal Triangle)
  • MacEwen's triangle is a key surgical landmark for identifying the mastoid antrum during mastoid surgery.
  • It is located on the mastoid process, the bony prominence behind the ear.
  • The triangle represents the lateral wall of the mastoid antrum.
  • Clinical importance of Macewen triangle: the antrum lies approximately 1.5 cm deep to the triangle. It is an important landmark to locate the mastoid antrum in mastoid surgery.
  • At birth, the lateral antral wall is about 2 mm thick and thickens by 1 mm per year, reaching 12-15 mm in adulthood.
  • The supramastoid crest corresponds to the floor of the middle cranial fossa.

Boundaries of MacEwen's Triangle
  • Superiorly: Temporal line (supramastoid crest)
  • Anteriorly: Posterosuperior part of the bony external auditory canal
  • Posteriorly: A tangent line drawn from the external auditory canal (Option C)

questions.text: Label the contents of middle ear appropriately

options.label: A
options.text: a-Incus, b-Stapedius, c-Stapes , d-Tensor tympani, e-Malleus

options.label: B
options.text: a-Incus, b-Stapes, c-Stapedius , d-Tensor tympani, e-Malleus

options.label: C
options.text: a-Incus, b-Tensor tympani, c-Stapes , d-Stapedius, e-Malleus

options.label: D
options.text: a-Malleus, b-Stapedius, c-Stapes , d-Tensor tympani, e- Incus

questions.correct_answer: A. a-Incus, b-Stapedius, c-Stapes , d-Tensor tympani, e-Malleus
questions.explanation:
Middle Ear

The middle ear is an air-filled cavity extending from the tympanic membrane, including the eustachian tube, aditus, antrum, and mastoid air cells (collectively called the middle ear cleft).

Walls of the Middle Ear (Six-Sided Box)
  • Roof (Tegmen Tympani): Thin bone separating the tympanic cavity from the middle cranial fossa, extending to form the roof of the aditus and antrum.
  • Floor: Thin bone separating the tympanic cavity from the jugular bulb, sometimes deficient leading to jugular bulb projection.
  • Anterior Wall: Thin bone between the cavity and internal carotid artery; contains openings for the eustachian tube and tensor tympani muscle.
  • Posterior Wall: Features the pyramid (stapedius tendon), aditus (connecting attic and antrum), and facial nerve.
  • Medial Wall: Formed by the labyrinth, includes the promontory (cochlea bulge), oval and round windows, facial nerve canal, lateral semicircular canal prominence, and sinus tympani.
  • Lateral Wall: Primarily the tympanic membrane, with the scutum (bony outer attic wall) contributing.

Contents of the Middle Ear
  • Ossicles: Malleus, incus, and stapes transmit sound from the tympanic membrane to the inner ear.
  • Intratympanic Muscles: Tensor tympani (attaches to malleus) and stapedius (attaches to stapes, dampens loud sounds).
  • Chorda Tympani Nerve: A branch of the facial nerve, carries taste from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue and controls salivary glands.
  • Tympanic Plexus:
    • The tympanic plexus is located on the promontory and is formed by
      • Tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve
      • Sympathetic fibres from the plexus around the internal carotid artery.
    • It innervates the middle ear, mastoid air cells, and eustachian tube.
  • Air: The middle ear is air-filled, lined by mucous membrane.

questions.text: Which structure, located in the petrous part of the temporal bone, is responsible for transmitting the facial nerve (VII) and is commonly involved in pathological conditions such as acoustic neuroma affecting the cerebellopontine angle?
questions.explanation:
Anatomy of the Temporal Bone

Segments

1. Tympanic: Forms the external auditory canal (EAC).

2. Mastoid:

  • Contains the mastoid air cell system, which is essential for ventilation and drainage of the middle ear.
  • Includes the antrum, connected to the epitympanum, and surrounded by air cells.

3. Petrous:

  • Most medial part, containing the cochlea, vestibule, semicircular canals and internal auditory canal.
  • Houses the facial nerve (VII) and vestibulocochlear nerve (VIII).

4. Squamous: Flat part of the temporal bone that contributes to the lateral skull wall, providing attachment points for muscles and ligaments.


 

Important associated Structures
  • Cranial Nerves:
    • Facial nerve (VII) and Vestibulocochlear nerve (VIII) passes through the internal auditory canal
    • 9th, 10th, and 11th cranial nerves (glossopharyngeal, vagus, accessory) run through the jugular foramen.
  • Vascular Structures:
    • Jugular bulb and carotid artery run near the petrous portion, making the temporal bone a critical area for surgical considerations.
    • Labyrinthine artery passes through the internal auditory canal
    • Internal Jugular Veins make their way out of the cranium and terminate at the subclavian veins via jugular foramen.
  • Other structures: Internal auditory canal, cochlea, vestibule, semicircular canals, vestibular aqueduct, endolymphatic sac.

questions.text: Patient underwent surgery for cholesteatoma 1 year back, now has presented with similar complaints again. Which among the following is the most common site of residual cholesteatoma?
questions.explanation:
Promontory
  • Bulge caused by the basal coil of the cochlea.

Oval Window
  • Footplate of the stapes is attached
  • Located below the facial nerve canal

Round Window (Fenestra Cochleae)
  • Covered by the secondary tympanic membrane.

Canal for Facial Nerve
  • Located above the oval window
  • Nerve may be exposed due to dehiscence

Prominence of Lateral Semicircular Canal
  • Located above the canal for the facial nerve

Processus Cochleariformis
  • Hook-like projection anterior to the oval window
  • Landmark for tensor tympani tendon attachment
  • First genu of the facial nerve

Sinus Tympani (Option B)
  • Deep recess medial to the pyramid
  • Bounded by the subiculum (below) and ponticulus (above)
  • Most common site for residual/recurrent cholesteatoma.

Facial recess
  • Bounded by vertical segment of facial nerve, chorda tympani and fossa incudis.
  • Surgical landmark for posterior tympanotomy.

questions.text: A 6-year old child was brought to clinic with recurrent episodes of upper respiratory tract infection. Child also complains of earache during this episodes. Doctor suspects that a structure exiting from anterior wall in middle ear is responsible for his earache. Arrange the following structures in order related to the wall (superior-to-inferior) 1) Internal carotid artery 2) Pharyngo-tympanic tube 3) Tensor tympani
questions.explanation:
1) Supratubal recess
  • Superior most, present in anterior epitympanum

2) Canal of Tensor tympani (Statement-3)
  • Tensor tympani subsequently runs along the medial wall

3) Pharyngo-tympanic tube (Statement-2)
  • Present in middle 3rd, 5x4mm diameter opening

4) Internal carotid artery (Statement-1)
  • Present in lower 3rd, bony plate covers the artery

questions.text: Which among the following are components of the middle ear cleft? 1) Tympanic plexus 2) Stapedius muscle 3) Mastoid air cells 4) Eustachian tube
A 50-year-old woman presents with a traumatic perforation of the tympanic membrane. The image is given below. What type of perforation is this?
Which of the following statements is false?

options.label: A
options.text: Pars tensa forms the majority of the tympanic membrane

options.label: B
options.text: Umbo is central part of pars tensa

questions.explanation:
Pars Tensa



 
  • Forms most of the tympanic membrane. (Option A)
  • Annulus Tympanicus - Thickened fibrocartilaginous ring at the periphery that fits into the tympanic sulcus.
  • Umbo - Central part of pars tensa (Option B), tented inward at the tip of the malleus.
  • Cone of Light - Bright reflection radiating from the tip of the malleus to the periphery in the anteroinferior quadrant.

Pars Flaccida (Shrapnell’s Membrane)

(Option C)
  • Located above the lateral process of the malleus, between the notch of Rivinus and the malleal folds.
  • Less taut and may appear slightly pinkish.

Outer Epithelial Layer

Continuous with the skin lining the external auditory meatus.

Inner Mucosal Layer

Continuous with the mucosa of the middle ear.

Middle Fibrous Layer
  • Contains radial, circular, and parabolic fibers and encloses the handle of the malleus.
  • In Pars Flaccida - Thin and not organized into distinct fibers as seen in pars tensa.

questions.text: Which of the following statements on tympanic membrane is false?

options.label: A
options.text: Partition between the external acoustic canal and the middle ear.

options.label: B
options.text: The posterosuperior part is more medial than the anteroinferior part.

questions.correct_answer: B. The posterosuperior part is more medial than the anteroinferior part.

questions.text: Match the parts of the external ear with the corresponding nerve supply Part Nerve supply a.Lower half of medial and lateral surface of pinna 1.Auricular branch of vagus nerve b.Retroauricular groove of the pinna 2.Facial nerve c.Floor of external auditory canal 3.Greater auricular nerve
questions.explanation:
Part

Nerve supply

Most of the medial surface of pinna- lower half and posterior part of the lateral surface

Greater auricular nerve (C2,3)

Upper part of the medial surface

Lesser occipital nerve (C2)

Tragus, crus of helix, and adjacent part of the helix

Auriculotemporal nerve (V3)

Concha and corresponding eminence on the medial surface

Auricular branch of vagus (CN X, Arnold’s nerve)

Concha and retroauricular groove

Facial nerve (CN VII) distributed with fibers of auricular branch of vagus

Part

Nerve supply

Anterior wall and roof

Auriculotemporal nerve (V3)

Posterior wall and floor

Auricular branch of vagus (CN X)

Posterior wall (additional supply)

Sensory fibers of facial nerve (CN VII) through auricular branch of vagus

Part

Nerve supply

Anterior half of lateral surface

auriculotemporal (V3)

Posterior half of lateral surface

auricular branch of vagus (CN X).

Medial surface

tympanic branch of CN IX (Jacobson’s nerve)

questions.text: A 3 year old child presents with swelling and pain in the region of the parotid gland, accompanied by ear discharge. Examination of the external auditory canal (EAC) reveals signs of infection. Which bony anatomical structure is responsible for the spread of infection between the EAC and the parotid gland?

A 10 year old boy presents with ear pain, swelling and redness around the ear. On examination, the external auditory canal is inflamed and furuncles are visible. What part of the external auditory canal is most likely affected?

options.label: A
options.text: Bony part of the external auditory canal

options.label: C
options.text: Cartilaginous part of the external auditory canal

questions.correct_answer: C. Cartilaginous part of the external auditory canal
questions.explanation:
External auditory canal
  • Connects outer ear to middle ear, from the concha to the tympanic membrane (eardrum).
  • Length & Shape:
    • Approximately 24 mm long (posterior wall).
    • Outer part angles upwards, backwards, and medially.
    • Inner part angles downwards, forwards, and medially.
  • Pinna must be pulled upwards, backwards, and laterally to view the eardrum.

Parts
  • Cartilaginous Part (Outer third, approximately 8 mm):
    • Continuous with pinna cartilage.
    • Fissures of Santorini allow infection to spread.
    • Thick skin with ceruminous glands and hair follicles.
    • Furuncles form here. (Option C)
  • Bony Part (Inner two-thirds, approximately 16 mm):
    • Thin skin extends over the tympanic membrane.
    • No hair or ceruminous glands.
    • Isthmus makes foreign body removal difficult.
    • Anterior recess collects debris in infections.
    • Foramen of Huschke (in children) allows infection to spread.

Relations
  • Superior: Middle cranial fossa
  • Posterior: Mastoid air cells, facial nerve
  • Inferior: Parotid gland
  • Anterior: Temporomandibular joint (TMJ)

questions.text: In reconstructive surgical procedures for nasal bridge deformities, if septal cartilage is unavailable, which part of the external ear is most commonly used as an alternative source for cartilage grafts?
